race.name: Gravel Brazil
race.tagline: Brazilian coastal mountains—100km, 2,000m elevation, steep technical terrain in beach town paradise.

terrain.surface: 80% gravel, 20% dirt roads. Brazilian coastal mountains—steep climbs, technical descents. Loose gravel on descents. 2,000 m over 100 km. Beach town start/finish. Technical rating: 4/5.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Brazil is Brazilian coastal mountains—100 km, 2,000 m elevation. Founded ~2019. 80% gravel, 20% dirt. Steep climbs, technical descents (loose gravel). 800-1,000 riders. Balneário Camboriú beach town. September spring conditions (18-28°C). Affordable entry (R$400-R$600 / $80-$120). If you want Brazilian gravel adventure with beach town vibes, this is it. If you want local/domestic race, skip it. International destination race.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Gravel Brazil is Brazilian coastal mountains with beach town finish. 100 km, 2,000 m, technical terrain. If you want Brazilian gravel destination race with affordable entry, this is it. If you want local/domestic, skip it. International travel required but beach town vibes and scenery make it worth it.

logistics.lodging_note: Balneário Camboriú beach town. Book early.
logistics.travel_summary: Fly to Florianópolis (FLN). Rental car needed (80 km, 1.5-hour drive to Balneário Camboriú). Beach town lodging—book early. Day-before packet pickup. Race September.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race party in beach town.

course_description.character: 100 km, 2,000 m. 80% gravel, 20% dirt. Brazilian coastal mountains. Steep climbs, technical descents. Technical rating: 4/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Coastal Mountain Climbs
suffering_zones.description: Steep Brazilian coastal mountains. 2,000 m cumulative.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Low gears. Pace conservatively. Steep. Heat/humidity management.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Technical Descents
suffering_zones.description: Loose gravel descents. Steep. Technical rating 4/5.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: 38-42mm tires. Pick lines. Brake early. Technical.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Heat/Humidity
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: 3+ bottles. Hydrate at every aid. Manage heat/humidity.

course_description.signature_challenge: Steep Brazilian coastal mountains (2,000 m / 100 km) + technical descents + heat/humidity.

history.origin_story: Gravel Brazil founded ~2019. Brazilian coastal mountains gravel. 100 km, 800-1,000 riders. Balneário Camboriú beach town. Growing Brazilian gravel scene.
history.reputation: Brazilian gravel scene. Coastal mountains. Beach town. International destination.

logistics.explanation: International travel to a race with minimal available logistics information creates planning nightmares. No details on packet pickup, parking, or accommodation strategies found anywhere. Registration open until March 1st suggests they're not overwhelmed with organization complexity.

length.explanation: The 2026 UCI Gravel World Series schedule lists Gravel Brazil at 111km for the elite category. 69km and 113km distance options let you pick your suffering level, but serious gravel addicts want more punishment for their international travel investment.

technicality.explanation: 650bisnotdead built specifically for Brazilian conditions: "I choose 650b for being far versatile than 700c for different tires. I can run 650x47 or 27,5x2.3." The need for such tire versatility suggests varied technical terrain demands. More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: 6,562 feet in 62 miles delivers over 100 feet of climbing per mile. The triple crankset setup with 50-39-30 and 11-40 cassette that local riders run suggests sustained climbing that demands very easy gearing options. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: March 8th puts you in Brazilian autumn—theoretically cooler than summer madness but still tropical humidity. Santa Catarina's coast means unpredictable weather patterns and potential for everything from blazing sun to sudden storms. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Balneário Camboriú starts at sea level—your lungs won't notice any difference. Even with significant climbing, you're not reaching altitudes that affect oxygen availability. This is elevation gain, not altitude training. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: First UCI gravel race in Southern America—you're literally writing the book. Santa Catarina's unexplored gravel territory means nobody knows what you're getting into. Racing in Brazil's coastal mountains delivers adventure, not manufactured experience. This is pure exploration disguised as a bike race.

prestige.explanation: First UCI Gravel race in Southern America carries serious weight—you're making history just by showing up. World Championship qualifier status puts it on the global radar, backed by the same crew running UCI Gran Fondo Brazil for years.

race_quality.explanation: UCI sanctioning means organization standards backed by the team behind Gran Fondo Brazil. They've been running serious cycling events annually for years. Still early to call it flawless without more rider feedback from multiple editions.

experience.explanation: You're pioneering gravel racing in Brazil—that's bucket list territory. Balneário Camboriú puts you in Santa Catarina's playground where mountains meet coast. The combination of being first to the party and racing unexplored gravel territory makes this unforgettable.

community.explanation: Brazilian cycling culture runs deep, with riders enthusiastic about sharing their builds for tropical conditions. Local framebuilding scene exists to support gravel riding. The Gran Fondo foundation means there's already a passionate local scene that knows how to celebrate suffering.

field_depth.explanation: Elite category at 111km draws World Championship qualification seekers, but international depth is still building. Being the only official Brazilian gravel race draws local talent. The real killers might still be figuring out this race exists. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three.

value.explanation: First gravel race in Southern America for unknown entry fees offers historical access at presumably reasonable Brazilian pricing. You're getting World Championship qualifying opportunity without European price tags. The experience-to-cost ratio tilts heavily toward riders.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs R$400. Getting to Balneário Camboriú means international flights for most riders, then domestic connections through Brazil's airport system. March timing avoids peak tourist season pricing. The real cost is in travel logistics, not local expenses. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: Brazil's first UCI gravel race arrives with World Championship stakes and zero track record—you're betting on potential over proof.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you need UCI points or want to say you raced Brazil's inaugural gravel event, this makes sense. The 6,562 feet of climbing over 62 miles suggests sustained suffering, not punchy attacks. Show up ready for humidity, unknown surfaces, and the chaos that comes with first-year events where nothing goes according to plan.
final_verdict.alternatives: Unbound Gravel gives you proven difficulty and community without the travel gamble. SBT GRVL delivers similar climbing with mountain views and established logistics if you want your suffering served with competence.

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: Technical all-rounder. EXO+ casing shrugs off rocks and roots.
